item.title: Little bit of java help
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“shangtsung1, post:16, topic:249409”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=328718.msg2576148#msg2576148 date=1228961253]

this wont give null pointer exception

String s = null;
if(s != null && s.length() > 0) {

}

this one will

String s = null;
if(s != null & s.length() > 0) {

}

You mean it can*. It won’t throw a NullPointerException unless s is null in the second one, which it may not be.
[/quote]

No, it WILL, since he declared s as null right before checking[/quote]

Oduh, stupidity on my part. Didn’t see that line lul. :o

Read full topic

[/quote]

No, it WILL, since he declared s as null right before checking

item.title: Little bit of java help

item.title: Little bit of java help
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“io9, post:11, topic:249409”]No. & and | perform operations on the operands, whereas && and || compare boolean values.

&& is not a shortcut to & because you can do x &= y, but you can’t do x &&= y.
Likewise for x |= y and x ||= y.

Also, & and | return values, i.e., 0x11001100 & 0x10101010 will give you 0x10011001, whereas 0xFFFFFFFF [true] && 0x00000000 [false] will give you false (0x00000000), and 0xFFFFFFFF [true] && 0xFFFFFFFF [true] will give you true (0xFFFFFFFF)

Although, if you mean in a boolean scope; then sure, & and && and | and || will have the same effect as the other.[/quote]

Not the same, similar effects as one another.

Assume the following:

int x = 5;
int y = 10;
if (x != 5 & y == 10) // will check both conditions even though the first is false, yet will be false because both are not true
if (x != 5 && y == 10) // will be false, but will only check the first one
if (x != 5 | y != 10) // will check both automatically and will be true because both are false
if (x == 5 || y != 10) // will check the first only and be false. Will only check the second if the first was true.

I’m honestly baffled that none of you learned to use & and | as conditional operators just as easily as || and &&. They are still equivalent to their bitwise counterparts, but are being used on non-integral datatypes.

[quote=“http://episteme.arstechnica.com/eve/forums/a/tpc/f/6330927813/m/4470911403”]Actually, using a single & or | evaluates the right hand operand no matter what the left hand one was. If you use && or || the right hand operand isn’t evaluated if the left invalidates the statement.
ie: If the left hand side of an && statement is false, the right hand side isn’t evaluated.[/quote]

http://www.java2s.com/Tutorial/Java/0060__Operators/versus.htm

Now stop arguing please.

Read full topic

item.title: Little bit of java help
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

No. & and | perform operations on the operands, whereas && and || compare boolean values.

&& is not a shortcut to & because you can do x &= y, but you can’t do x &&= y.
Likewise for x |= y and x ||= y.

Also, & and | return values, i.e., 0x11001100 & 0x10101010 will give you 0x10011001, whereas 0xFFFFFFFF [true] && 0x00000000 [false] will give you false (0x00000000), and 0xFFFFFFFF [true] && 0xFFFFFFFF [true] will give you true (0xFFFFFFFF)

Although, if you mean in a boolean scope; then sure, & and && and | and || will have the same effect as the other.

Read full topic

item.title: Little bit of java help
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“jGod, post:9, topic:249409”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=328718.msg2573282#msg2573282 date=1228794656]

uh, no, taharok.

operators such as ~, &, |, ^: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitwise_operation
operators such as ||, &&: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_operators

Yes, and & and | can both be used on boolean values and will perform the bitwise operations, thus making them boolean operators as well.
[/quote]

The bitwise will evaluate both conditions whereas the conditional will only evaluate one if necessary.[/quote]

Exactly, which is why && is a shortcut to &, since it will only check the second condition if the first is true, Opposite applies to | and ||.

Read full topic

item.title: Little bit of java help
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:4, topic:249409”][quote author=Coder xynt link=topic=328718.msg2571348#msg2571348 date=1228685676]
& is a bitwise operator while && is a conditional ‘and’
[/quote]

Actually, & and && are both conditional operators, but & is also a bitwise operator. && is what is known as the ‘shortcut & operator’. Same with | and ||.[/quote]
What the fuck are you on about?

Read full topic

item.title: Little bit of java help
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

On another topic

& is a bitwise operator while && is a conditional ‘and’

Actually, & and && are both conditional operators, but & is also a bitwise operator. && is what is known as the ‘shortcut & operator’. Same with | and ||.

Read full topic

[quote=“Daed, post:1, topic:249409”]Hey everyone, i’ve just picked up learning java again - my last try was a fail.

basically i’m making a rock paper scissors game, and i need to find a way of making a If-And statement, i tried it like this:

If(var == "1") & (var2 == "1") 
{ 
        // Code here
}

Please help :D[/quote]You should be using &&, & is a different operator.
